title: How it feels to have a good shen in your team

replies.body: Ugh, always hated going up against a good Six Samurai deck.

especially when your deck revolve around stronger monster cards as your main method of winning, or your deck doesn't have many special summon effect monster which means it's hard to compete with its infinte chain summoning mechanic.

(honestly i think season1 yugioh is the best, everything after than is just going down hill. too much new mechanics and systematic decks which means it's not about making your own deck by putting together cards but buy decks with built in strategies. stuff like samurai cards are useless in other decks.)

Its what happens when players get competitive. A meta develops and the game has to be designed around that outcome.

Oh wait were we talking about yugioh?

yugioh meta right now is completely decided by which broken deck they decide to release tho, there is no need for developing strategies anymore, buy any constructed deck and there is already a fully constructed strategy in it, and it is usually broken as fuck.
Thats why I switched to Magic. Expensive af to make a good deck. But you are not limited by card type unless you doing tribal or some shit like that.

That's how they get their money. It's a company, after all. Like Riot, they can't favor balance over profits. Zed isn't getting nerfs because to the unexperienced player or the non-player (in other words, the biggest customers and the potential customers), he is the absolute most fun champion to watch play. A dark, edgy shadow-ninja who can teleport and kill enemies while laughing darkly? Yeah. He might as well be their logo. Ninjas are always in. 

Likewise, though using a necessarily different business strategy, new decks are completely structured around you buying certain specific cards so you can win for a few months before they'e banned. After which, the cycle repeats and you buy the new broke cards before they're banned.
